speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I better be heading out.  Niles and I are meeting for dinner, and then we have tickets to the theatrical event of the season.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Sir Trevor Aimsley in "Tears of the Mariner."

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.

speaker: Frasier
text: It promises to be a very exciting evening.  You see, Seattle is Sir Trevor's last stop on his farewell tour.  After this, he's retiring from the stage forever.

speaker: Martin
text: "Tears of the Mariner."  You know, I think I read a review of that.  Thought it was one of those baseball stories like "Pride of the Yankees", you know?  But it's just about some crabby old sailor, stuck in this little town...

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, Dad, please.  I have carefully avoided all the reviews of this play.  I do not want to hear about it before I see it.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't want to hear about it after you see it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hello Daphne.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Daph.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's it?  "Hello Daphne"?  Haven't you seen the paper?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I glanced at it.  Why, did I miss something?

speaker: Daphne
text: Look!

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughing_] Oh, my gosh!  Is that you?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, good heavens, it's kind of hard to tell.  You've got your back turned to the camera, your skirts blown up around your... Oh, well, it must've been rather blustery out.

speaker: Daphne
text: I was in the park yesterday, and this photographer snapped my picture for the "It's Your Seattle" column - the one where they show some average person out and about, then use their name on the column.  For instance, if they used a picture of Mr. Crane, the caption would read "Martin Crane's Seattle." Or if they took one of you it would say "Frasier Crane's Se-"

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, we get it.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, don't crinkle it, I want to send it home to my family.

speaker: Martin
text: You sure about that?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, don't be such an old fogey.  So I'm bending down and me knickers are showing a bit, but my family'll still be proud as peacocks when they see that:  "Daphne Moon's Seattle".

speaker: Frasier
text: She certainly does. _He heads for the door.  Fade out.  Scene 2 - In Front of the Theater Fade in.  Frasier and Niles approach the entrance, sipping coffee._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, will you just stop it?  The dinner was just fine.

speaker: Niles
text: It was not fine.  I made those reservations weeks ago. They seated us so close to the kitchen I'm surprised they didn't make us wear hair nets.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sure it was just a mix-up.

speaker: Niles
text: It's not a mix-up.  It's part of an alarming trend I've noticed ever since Maris and I parted company.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Last week, Roberta Phipps snubbed me at the opera. I wasn't even invited to that gala fundrasier for St. Andrew's Orphanage.

speaker: Frasier
text: You can still send money to the children.

speaker: Niles
text: As usual, you've missed the point.  I'm being shut out. It's as if someone snuck into my world and changed all the locks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles. [_pulling out the tickets_] Well, at least you don't have to worry about that tonight.  After you.

speaker: Niles
text: Evening.

speaker: Usher
text: Tickets, please.

speaker: Usher
text: Oh, I'm sorry sir, these aren't for this performance.

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  But they say for the sixteenth, that's the sixteenth right there, that's today.

speaker: Usher
text: Yes sir, they were for the matinee.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, no, no there has to be some mistake, let me just... Oh, dear God.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm so sorry, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, surely you must hold some tickets aside for emergencies.  We'll take anything, anything at all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, even mezzanine.

speaker: Usher
text: If you like, you can try your luck in the cancellation line.

speaker: Niles
text: How could this happen?  I have to see this play.  I have to have people see me see this play.  If I'm not seen seeing this play, you see...

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, Niles, Niles!  I will make a simple phone call and we'll get house seats for tomorrow night, all right?

speaker: Niles
text: I suppose so.  Come on, let's go.  The last thing I need is for someone to see us loitering out here like gutter riff- raff pathetically scrounging for last minute tickets. _The people in the cancellation line are not really happy with this description and Frasier notices them._

speaker: Frasier
text: Good luck! **ANOTHER NIGHT AT THE THEATRE** _Scene 3 - Frasier's Apartment The doorbell rings.  Fade in.  Frasier answers the door to reveal Niles._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, I know I'm a bit early, I was hoping we could get a bite to eat before the theater.

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, Niles...

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, yeah, it'll be on me of course, as a thank you for getting those replacement tickets.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, about the tickets...

speaker: Niles
text: I know, I owe you money.  And my gratitude.  And if I keep talking, you won't be able to tell me you weren't able to get the tickets.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just haven't been able to get them yet...

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I KNEW you wouldn't get them!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, please.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, and now it's too late.  It's six o'clock.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, just calm down.  I've made a few well placed calls, I haven't heard back from a couple of people.  Someone will call.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, someone better call.  Because everyone who's anyone is seeing this play.  And you know who you are if you're not anyone?  You're NO ONE.  And I've been someone much too long to start being no one now.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, hey, I thought no one was here. [_Niles begins to throw another fit_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, please, just relax.  One way or another, we are going to get tickets to this play.

speaker: Martin
text: You two still going on about those tickets?  If this play is any good at all, in a coupla years they'll do it down at the dinner theater and you can get a nice prime rib with it. _Niles and Frasier are shocked and stand with their mouths agape in their classic "Did he actually SAY that?" look._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you don't understand.  You see, this isn't just about the play.  This is literally our last opportunity to see one of the finest actors of our time.

speaker: Martin
text: You just want to go 'cause all your snobby friends are goin' and you don't want to feel left out.

speaker: Niles
text: What we want is to sit at a theater and share a transcendent experience.

speaker: Martin
text: That nobody else could get tickets to.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course.  That's the transcendent part. _Frasier and Martin share a smile at this.  The phone rings, Niles eagerly picks it up and hands it to Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello? ... Yes, I'll hold. [_to Niles_] It's Cleo Fenwick.

speaker: Niles
text: Cleo Fenwick?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you remember her, she's on the board of the theater. You've seen her: bad eye-job, dowager's hump you could cross the Sahara on. [_into phone_] Hello, Cleo, you lovely thing.  Uh-huh.  Oh, well, you're a dear for trying.  Thanks. Oh, don't despair Niles, I'm getting another call.  Hello? Yes, Dora!  Yes, uh-huh.  Too bad.  Well, thank you.  Yeah, oh, that is a wonderful idea, yes I will!  Thank you, bye-bye. [_He disconnects._]

speaker: Niles
text: She has a lead for us?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, she said I should call Cleo Fenwick.

speaker: Niles
text: This is hopeless.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, there is another way.

speaker: Niles
text: You don't mean...

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  I know it's a calculated risk.  It is a little uncertain.

speaker: Niles
text: You can't be serious.  It's unthinkable.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what other choice do we have?

speaker: Niles
text: But the indignity, it reeks of desperation.

speaker: Martin
text: Now, now, before you do anything desperate, at least go stand in the cancellation line. [_exits to kitchen_]

speaker: Niles
text: What did he think we were talking about? _Frasier shrugs, just as confused.  Fade out.  Scene 4 - In Front of the Theater Fade in.  Niles and Frasier are at the head of the cancellation line._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh no it's Stephen and Susan Kendall.  Quick, turn around. If they see us here, we'll be ruined.  They know everybody.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I know.  Their Sunday brunches are a Who's Who of Seattle's elite.

speaker: Niles
text: [_glancing over his shoulder_] I think it's safe.  No one saw us.

speaker: Roz
text: [_calling out and hurrying over_] Hey, Frasier!  Niles!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz.  What are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: And how did you get tickets?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, a friend of mine couldn't use hers, so she gave them to me.  I asked my cute new dentist, he's a big fan of Sir What's-his-face.

speaker: Frasier
text: You refer to the world's greatest living actor as...

speaker: Niles
text: Now, now, Frasier.  Roz may not be familiar with Sir Trevor, but I'm sure she'll enjoy the play.  I trust you got good seats?

speaker: Roz
text: [_taking the tickets out to check_] Ooh. I think so.  Row C?

speaker: Niles
text: Row C.  Excellent. [_then_] Look, a whole bunch of naked men. _Roz turns around and Niles grabs the tickets in her hand but she doesn't let go._

speaker: Roz
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Niles
text: Give me those, you philistine!  You don't even know his name!

speaker: Roz
text: Are you crazy?! _She kicks him in the shin, causing him to yelp "Ouch!" and let go of the tickets.  Roz's date walks up._

speaker: Rob
text: Ready to go, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Mandell?

speaker: Rob
text: Oh, hi, Niles.

speaker: Roz
text: You two know each other?

speaker: Rob
text: Sure.  How's the teeth bleaching going?

speaker: Niles
text: [_folding his lips over his teeth_] Fine, thanks.

speaker: Roz
text: Let's go, Rob.  It's a long way to row C from the cancellation line. [_She heads for the entrance._]

speaker: Rob
text: Hang in there, guys.  I wouldn't be surprised if you get lucky.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd be stupefied if you didn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: I knew you were bleaching them.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh...

speaker: Frasier
text: "No, really, I just changed toothpastes."

speaker: Susan
text: Is that Niles Crane?  And Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Susan.

speaker: Niles
text: Stephen.

speaker: Susan
text: We're seeing everybody tonight.  It simply... oh, dear. You're not waiting for a cancellation, are you?

speaker: Niles
text: Is that what this is?

speaker: Frasier
text: I feel just... Look at us.  Blocking these poor unfortunates who couldn't get tickets.

speaker: Seller
text: I got one pair left.  Who's next?

speaker: Usher
text: Curtain going up.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_ushering the Kendalls along_] Curtain going up, shall we?

speaker: Seller
text: Next in line, please.

speaker: Susan
text: Niles, you coming?

speaker: Niles
text: I, uh...

speaker: Frasier
text: You'll have to forgive my brother.  You see, he's too ashamed to admit he's just waiting for one last cigarette.  It's all right, Niles, you go right ahead, I'll just see the Kendalls in.

speaker: Niles
text: OK.

speaker: Stephen
text: Thank God, another smoker.  Darling, maybe I'll just stay and have a cigarette with Niles.

speaker: Seller
text: Do you want these tickets, sir?

speaker: Niles
text: Me?  Oh, oh, no, no! [_He steps aside for the next people in line._]

speaker: Susan
text: Stephen, please.  I'd really like to sit down.

speaker: Stephen
text: All right.  Niles, we'll make a date.  I'll meet you right here at intermission and we'll have a smoke.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, right here is where I'll be.

speaker: Frasier
text: Enjoy.

speaker: Susan
text: See you later.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, this is just perfect.  Not only are we missing the play, but now we have to hang around here until intermission, so they don't catch on to us.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, what are you complaining about?  I'm the one who has an hour to learn how to smoke.  _End of Act 1  Act 2  Scene 1 - In Front of the Theater Frasier is sitting on a light post base.  Niles has a cigarette out. The theater starts emptying for intermission._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  They're coming out.  Come on, let's blend in.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what are you doing?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm practicing.  I haven't held a cigarette since I played Duke Mantee in our junior high production of "The Petrified Forest."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I remember watching you from the petrified audience. Come on.  Oh, there they are, let's go.

speaker: Stephen
text: Oh, well, you got out here quickly.  I guess you needed one of these more than I did, huh?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, well, when you enjoy smoking as much as I do, noth... [_Having taken a puff, he breaks down coughing._]

speaker: Susan
text: Oh, bye-bye.  Feel better, I'll call you.

speaker: Stephen
text: The Gornleys.  Kendra isn't feeling well, Richard is taking her home.  Oh, there's Mikki and Lyle.

speaker: Susan
text: Poor old dears, they could only get balcony.

speaker: Stephen
text: Still, we should say hello.  They are your parents.  Excuse us.

speaker: Niles
text: [_crushing out his cigarette_] My God, these things are turning me green!

speaker: Frasier
text: Never mind that, Niles.  The Gornleys are not coming back. Let's go sneak into their seats and watch the second act.

speaker: Niles
text: Let's go!

speaker: Usher
text: Your ticket stubs, please.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I beg your pardon?

speaker: Usher
text: Well, I'm sorry, we've had some people try to sneak in after intermission.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, I think we, I left our coats in our seats and our stubs are in the coats.

speaker: Usher
text: Oh, don't worry about it. [_They turn to head in, but are stopped again._] We'll just have someone bring your coats to you.  Where are your seats?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll...have to check the seating chart.

speaker: Stephen
text: Aren't you going in?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes, yes, my brother just needed to have one last cigarette.

speaker: Susan
text: Oh, you're worse than Stephen.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, really, Niles, I do wish you'd quit.  I'm begging you.

speaker: Niles
text: I just wish I didn't love the damn things so much. [_He lights up._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, if we don't see you after, have a lovely evening.

speaker: Susan
text: Actually, we're having a small supper at Le Chanteuse afterwards for Sir Trevor.  So if you're not busy, say around eleven?

speaker: Susan
text: Good, we'll see you then.

speaker: Niles
text: [_stamping out the cigarette_] Frasier!  Dinner with Sir Trevor, that's better than seeing the play!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, are you insane?  We know absolutely nothing about the damn play!  How can we possibly talk with this man? For God's sake, I just wish I'd read that review in yesterday's paper.

speaker: Niles
text: Do you still have it?

speaker: Frasier
text: I might.  Dad lets the papers pile up for days sometimes. You know what?  We've got just enough time to go there and get back.  Let's go!

speaker: Stephen
text: Where are you going?

speaker: Frasier
text: See, I told you it was the other way. _They come up behind the Kendalls, then rush away as soon as their backs are turned._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_muttering_] God! _FADE TO:  Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment Frasier and Niles are in the kitchen, rummaging through the papers. Martin comes in._

speaker: Martin
text: What's goin' on?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, we're looking for yesterday's paper.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, well, it should be there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Dad!  That review you were reading yesterday, "Tears of the Mariner."  Do you remember it?

speaker: Martin
text: [_unsure_] Kinda.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just concentrate: What was the play about?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, let me see, uh, it started out with this old guy who was guttin' a fish.  And then he gives this fish to his son, but his son rejects it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good!  Good, then what?

speaker: Martin
text: Uh...oh, yeah!  Well, then it turns out he's got this fatal disease, and the next thing you know, he's in this big stadium.  And he's telling everyone that even though he's dying, that today, he considers himself the luckiest...

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad!  That is "Pride of the Yankees"!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah, that's right.  I'm sorry, I'm sorry about that. But I'm pretty sure that fish part was right.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, yes!  Here it is!

speaker: Frasier
text: Let me see:  "Trevor Aimsley's bravura performance in 'Tears of the Mariner' qualifies him as an..."  Yes, blah blah blah, blah blah blah, continued on page A-sixteen. _He flips to the back of the section and opens it up, only to find that there is a huge hole cut in the page._

speaker: Niles
text: Where is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne!  Her picture must have been on the other side.  It may still be here, she was going to mail it to her mother. [_He heads to the living room._]

speaker: Niles
text: [_following_] Daphne's picture was in the paper?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well someone snapped a candid photo of her in the park. If you ask me, it was not her most flattering angle, but I'm sure you would disagree. [_He grabs Daphne's letter._]

speaker: Niles
text: Well, open it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Carefully... Oh, what the hell, I'll buy her flowers. _He rips it open and starts to pull out the piece of newspaper. Daphne comes in the front door and Frasier freezes._

speaker: Daphne
text: Hey, Dr. Crane, I thought you went... Is that my letter?

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, let me explain...

speaker: Daphne
text: [_grabbing the letter_] No, no, I should have known I'd never get any privacy in this house.

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't understand.  I just wanted to...

speaker: Daphne
text: You just wanted to find out if I was gossiping about you to my mum.  Well, fine!  I was.  A seventy-three year old woman in Manchester is about to find out that you dye the grey out of your temples.  There!  You happy?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I am not happy, I am mortified! [_he pauses_] How did you know that?  I keep my hair dye in the false bottom of my cufflink box.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well...  I'll let it go this time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, we haven't got time for this!  We've to get down to that party!

speaker: Niles
text: I knew you were dyeing your hair.

speaker: Frasier
text: Shut up.

speaker: Niles
text: "No, no, really, it's just my new conditioner."

speaker: Frasier
text: Shut up! _They exit.  Fade out.  Scene 3 - The Restaurant Fade in.  Frasier and Niles are sitting at the bar._

speaker: Frasier
text: Whatever you do, don't get specific about the play.  That's the mistake you made last year when you lied about having seen "The Silent Echo."  All that yammering on about how the play had third act problems.  It fooled no one.

speaker: Niles
text: What makes you so sure?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for starters, "The Silent Echo" doesn't have a third act. _Sir Trevor Aimsley enters to applause and cries of "Bravo!"  He bows and heads towards the bar._

speaker: Trevor
text: Thank you. [_then_] God, I need a drink. [_to bartender_] Double scotch, no ice.

speaker: Bartender
text: Yes, sir.

speaker: Susan
text: Frasier, Niles, how nice.  Sir Trevor, this is Dr. Frasier Crane and his brother Dr. Niles Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shaking his hand_] It's an honor.

speaker: Susan
text: Two of our city's preeminent psychiatrists.

speaker: Niles
text: [_shaking his hand_] Huge fans.

speaker: Frasier
text: Huge, yes.

speaker: Susan
text: They've set up a table for us in the private room, shall we?

speaker: Trevor
text: No, I'll just finish this and be right along.  Perhaps the two doctors will keep me company.  I'd love to hear a psychological interpretation of the play.

speaker: Susan
text: All right, but don't be too long. [_She leaves._]

speaker: Trevor
text: So, tell me, as students of the human psyche, did my character ring true?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh yes.  So true.

speaker: Niles
text: I can honestly say I never saw a false moment.

speaker: Trevor
text: Well, what about the third act?  The play clearly has a third act problem.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, at least it has a third act, unlike "The Silent Echo" which really could have used one. [_Frasier gives him a dark look._]

speaker: Trevor
text: I quite agree.  I did "The Silent Echo" in London, last year. What did you think of the hat scene? [_Frasier now gives Niles a cheery "What now?" look._]

speaker: Niles
text: The hat scene?  Well, you know, the most important thing about the hat scene, and I have to stress this... oh dear God, is that clock right?  I have to call the sitter and tell her I'm going to be late.  The children worry so. [_He rushes off._]

speaker: Trevor
text: Well, back to the play.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  Well, you, of course, were brilliant.

speaker: Trevor
text: Oh, please!  Dr. Crane, I just want your professional analysis of what you saw tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it, uh... of course I could discuss subtext, metaphor and imagery with you, but you see, I, I come to the theater to feel.  To be moved, and that is exactly what happened to me tonight.

speaker: Trevor
text: Really?  When?

speaker: Frasier
text: When?  Well, let me see...uh, um, well, there was that, uh, the gutting the fish scene.  You make the most heart-breaking gesture...  It was, uh, you know, the one with, with your hands... [_He motions vaguely._]

speaker: Trevor
text: Oh, you mean when I offer the fish to my son and he turns his back to me and I reach out to him like this? [_does so_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it's even more moving the second time.  Well, who knows why a, a moment like that touches us so.  You see, that is your gift, Sir Trevor.  You've given us hundreds of moments.  Moments so real, so compelling that we are revealed in their truth.

speaker: Trevor
text: You don't know how refreshing this is.  To meet someone who doesn't just come to the theater, but who gives himself over to it.  That crowd in there, they only come because it's fashionable.  They don't care about art.  I can spot them at a glance: the poseur, the fraud.  Oh, here comes your brother.

speaker: Niles
text: [_sitting down again_] Kids are fine.

speaker: Trevor
text: Oh.

speaker: Waitress
text: Excuse me Sir Trevor, they're waiting for you in the dining room.

speaker: Trevor
text: Ah, very well. [_stands up and takes Frasier by the shoulders_] And thank you, Dr. Crane, for your integrity and your passion. You are the reason that actors act. _He exits, not noticing Frasier nearly weeping as the full realization of what he passed up hits him._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm sorry I deserted you but obviously you carried the day.  Bravo!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_disgusted with himself_] Oh, yes, bravo for us! _Catching Frasier's tone, Niles loses his cheer and sinks onto the stool next to Frasier's._

speaker: Niles
text: [_half-expecting the answer_] What do you mean?

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you realize what we missed tonight?  A potentially life-changing experience in the theater.  And why? Because we were too embarrassed to be seen in a cancellation line.

speaker: Niles
text: You're right.  What were we thinking?  Kowtowing to a group of snobs like that.

speaker: Frasier
text: We weren't thinking.  Come on, let's get out of here.

speaker: Susan
text: Frasier, Niles.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Susan, I'm so sorry, but we can't stay.

speaker: Susan
text: Oh, no.  Sir Trevor will be so disappointed.  He was quite taken with you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, send him our apologies.  It really was wonderful to meet him.

speaker: Susan
text: I know this is short notice, but if you're free this weekend, we're having one of our Sunday brunches.  Senator Logan is coming and Maria DeFalco and the Whitneys...

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but I'm afraid that we...

speaker: Susan
text: Oh, please try.  I'll hold it open for you.  Check your books and let me know. [_She goes back to the dining room._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, how's that for irony?

speaker: Niles
text: Sunday brunch at the Kendalls'.  An hour ago we would have leapt at that invitation.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not anymore.  We've got a damn sight too much integrity. [_They start to leave._] Although... Are we being selfish?

speaker: Niles
text: Possibly.  How?

speaker: Frasier
text: Here's my thinking.  Why do shallow people remain that way? The lack of positive influence.

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps our brand of integrity is just what that group needs.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!  We can be like those politicians who try to change the system from within.

speaker: Niles
text: Exactly.  And who knows?  Maybe it'll rub off on Senator Logan, he'll bring it back with him to Washington.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well now we HAVE to go.

speaker: Niles
text: What are you wearing?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm going to wear my new Prada suit.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you're a fashion plate and a patriot.
